questions.text: 1. A patient presents to the OPD with fever. Which area is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
The area most likely involved in fever is the Preoptic nucleus.

The preoptic area contains large numbers of heat-sensitive neurons. These neurons function as temperature sensors for controlling body temperature. When the preoptic area is heated, the skin all over the body starts sweating, whereas the skin blood vessels over the entire body become dilated. This response is an immediate reaction to help the body to lose heat, thereby helping to return the body temperature toward the normal level. In addition to this, any excess body heat production is inhibited.

The pathogenesis of fever involves:

* Release of toxins from bacteria, such as endotoxin

* Toxins act on monocytes, macrophages, and Kupffer cells to produce cytokines that act as endogenous pyrogens

* These circulating cytokines are polypeptides that act on the OVLT, one of the circumventricular organs

* This in turn, activates the preoptic area of the hypothalamus

* Raise in temperature set point leading to fever

questions.text: 2. What will be seen during rapid ascent to high altitude?
questions.solution:
Respiratory alkalosis will be seen during rapid ascent to high altitude.

At High Altitudes:

* The composition of air stays the same, but the total barometric pressure falls with increasing altitude, leading to a fall in PO2

* Hypoxic stimulation of the chemoreceptors under normal breathing causes increased ventilation

* Alveolar PO2 falls less rapidly, and the alveolar PCO2 declines because of the hyperventilation

* Fall in arterial PCO2 produces respiratory alkalosis

* To compensate for this respiratory alkalosis, the kidneys reduce hydrogen ion secretion and increase bicarbonate excretion

questions.text: 3. In uncontrolled diabetes, in which of the following cells is there decreased glucose uptake due to insulin deficiency?
questions.solution:
There is decreased glucose uptake in skeletal muscle due to insulin deficiency. 

GLUT-4 is the transporter in skeletal muscle, heart and adipose tissue that is stimulated by insulin. A pool of GLUT-4 molecules is maintained within vesicles in the cytoplasm of insulin-sensitive cells. Insulin results in the transport of GLUT-4 from intracellular vesicles to the cell membrane by activating phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase.

Insulin-sensitive tissues also contain a group of GLUT-4 vesicles that move into the cell membrane in response to exercise, leading to lower blood sugar after exercise. This process occurs independently of the action of insulin, and 5′-adenosine monophosphate–activated kinase helps to trigger the insertion of these vesicles into the cell membrane.

questions.text: 4. Which of the following molecules is structurally most similar to IGF-1 and IGF-2?
questions.solution:
Proinsulin is structurally most similar to IGF-1 and IGF-2.

Insulin-like growth factors are polypeptide factors with a similar structure to proinsulin. They have intact C chains and an extra domain attached to the A chain called the D domain. The two IGFs in humans are IGF-I and IGF-II. 

IGF-II has 67 amino acid residues wile IGF-I is a single-chain polypeptide of 70 amino acid residues cross-linked by three disulfide bridges.

questions.text: 5. Tight junctions are present in which of the following epithelial domains?
questions.solution:
Tight junctions are present in the apicolateral part of the epithelium.

Tight junctions, also known as zonula occludens, tie cells together and endow tissues with strength and stability. They are made up of ridges—half from one cell and half from the other—which adhere so strongly at cell junctions that they almost obliterate the space between the cells. They permit the passage of ions, solutes and intracellular signalling molecules between adjacent cells. 

There are three main families of transmembrane proteins that contribute to tight junctions:

* Occludin

* Junctional adhesion molecules

* Claudins 

It is present in epithelia such as the intestinal mucosa, walls of the renal tubules, and the choroid plexus. They are important for endothelial barrier function and endothelium-dependent vasodilation. They prevent the movement of proteins in the plane of the membrane, which helps to maintain the different distribution of transporters and channels that make transport across epithelia possible.

questions.text: 6. The surface tension of the fluid lining the alveoli increases during

choices.text: Change in posture from standing to supine
Change in posture from supine to standing

questions.solution:
The surface tension of the fluid lining the alveoli increases during Inspiration.

The surface tension is low when the alveoli are small due to the presence of surfactant in the fluid lining the alveoli. Surface tension increases as the alveolar size increases during inspiration. 

As per the Laplace law,



where,

P = Collapsing pressure on alveolus (dynes/cm2) or Pressure required to keep alveoli open

T = Surface tension (dynes/cm)

r = Radius of the alveolus (cm)

Collapsing pressure is inversely related to radius, i.e., a large alveolus (one with a large radius) will have a low collapsing pressure and therefore will require only minimal pressure to keep it open. On the other hand, a small alveolus (one with a small radius) will have a high collapsing pressure and require more pressure to keep it open.

Pearl PM1012: Pulmonary surfactant

It lowers the surface tension of the water layer at the alveolar surface, which increases lung compliance, thereby making it easier for the lungs to expand. It is secreted by type II alveolar cells. It is a mixture of phospholipids and protein.

4 unique apoproteins of surfactant: Surfactant proteins are (SP)-A, SP-B, SP-C, and SP-D.

* SP-A - Regulation of the feedback uptake of surfactant by the type II alveolar epithelial cells that secrete it.

* SP-B & SP-C - Key protein members of the monomolecular film of surfactant.

* SP-D - Organization of SP-B and SP-C into the surfactant layer.

A deep breath increases its secretion by stretching the type II cells. Its concentration decreases when breaths are small.

In the fetus, surfactant synthesis is variable. The surfactant may be present as early as gestational week 24 and is almost always present by gestational week 35.

questions.text: 7. During a simple muscle twitch experiment, latent period = 10 ms, contraction period = 40 ms, relaxation period= 20 ms. What is the fusion frequency that is required to tetanize this muscle in Hz.
questions.solution:
The tetanising frequency of the given skeletal muscle is 25 per second.

Tetanising frequency = 1/contraction period (per second)

Therefore, tetanising frequency = 1/40 per millisecond = 1000/40 per second = 25 per second = 25 Hz

With repeated stimulation, contraction occurs repeatedly before any relaxation has occurred. This causes the individual responses to fuse into one continuous contraction. Such a response is called tetanus (tetanic contraction). ​​​Tetanising frequency is the minimum frequency required for producing tetanus.

Tetanus is of two types: complete tetanus, when no relaxation occurs between stimuli, and incomplete tetanus, when periods of incomplete relaxation occur between the summated stimuli. 

When there is a repeated stimulus to a muscle fibre before relaxation, it produces an additional contraction of the muscle. The second contraction adds to the first contraction and the total strength of contraction increases. This phenomenon is known as a summation of contractions.

questions.text: 8. Which of the following is an example of a feedforward mechanism in homeostasis?

choices.text: Increased cardiac output in severe anemia
Increase heart rate when standing up from supine position

questions.solution:
Vasoconstriction on cooling of the skin is an example of a feedforward mechanism in homeostasis.

Feed-forward control is used to apprise the brain whether a muscle movement is performed correctly. If not, the brain corrects the feed-forward signals that it sends to the muscle the next time the movement is required. This mechanism is often called adaptive control.

Examples include

* Temperature regulation – The hypothalamus initiates thermoregulatory responses before the changes in environmental temperature have succeeded in changing the body’s core body temperature

* Stimulation of gastric acid secretion

* Parathyroid hormone stimulating the production of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D

Other options:

Options A, B and D: Increased cardiac output in severe anaemia, increased vasopressin secretion during dehydration and increased heart rate when standing up from the supine position are all examples of negative feedback mechanism.

questions.text: 9. During the recording of the EEG, a resting and awake person was instructed to close his eyes and then open them. The dominant wave which decreases on opening the eyes is?
questions.solution:
The dominant wave, which decreases on opening the eyes, is the Alpha wave.

A resting and awake person, when closes his eyes and then opens them to focus attention on something, the alpha rhythm gets replaced by an irregular, low-voltage beta rhythm. This phenomenon is known as alpha block. This can be produced by any form of sensory stimulation or mental concentration, such as solving arithmetic problems.

This is also known as the arousal or alerting response because it is correlated with the aroused, alert state. It has also been called desynchronization because it represents the breaking up of the synchronised neural activity necessary to produce regular waves. However, the term desynchronization is misleading because the rapid EEG activity seen in the alert state is also synchronised, but at a higher rate.

questions.text:
10. The Bezold-Jarisch reflex typically leads to

1. Hypopnea 2. Bradycardia 3. Hypotension  4. Tachycardia
questions.solution:
The Bezold-Jarisch reflex typically leads to hypopnea, bradycardia and hypotension.

The Bezold–Jarisch reflex is a cardiovascular response triggered by chemosensitive vagal C fibres in the heart and lungs, leading to profound bradycardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea, followed by rapid, shallow breathing. It can be activated by substances like capsaicin, serotonin, phenylbiguanide, and veratridine. and serotonin or during myocardial ischemia and coronary angiography, contributing to hypotension in heart disease. It also serves a protective role by limiting toxic substance absorption from the lungs.

This reflex can be activated during myocardial ischemia and reperfusion because of increased production of oxygen radicals and by agents used as radiocontrast for coronary angiography. Activation of cardiopulmonary chemosensitive receptors may also be part of a defence mechanism protecting individuals from toxic chemical hazards, and it may help reduce the amount of inspired pollutants that get absorbed into the blood. This protects vital organs from the potential toxicity of these pollutants and facilitates their elimination. Vasovagal syncope has also been attributed to activation of the Bezold–Jarisch reflex.

questions.text: 11. The antidiuretic hormone (ADH) leads to secretion of concentrated urine by all of the following mechanisms except

choices.text: Increases water permeability in collecting ducts
Increased absorption of urea from descending limb of loop of Henle
Increased reabsorption of sodium from thick ascending limb of loop of Henle
Increased absorption of urea  from medullary collecting duct

questions.solution:
The antidiuretic hormone (ADH) leads to the secretion of concentrated urine by all of the mentioned mechanisms except for increased absorption of urea from the descending limb of the loop of Henle.    

The primary action of ADH on the kidneys is to enhance absorption of water from the tubular fluid or leads to secretion of concentrated urine by:

* Increasing the water permeability of the distal tubule and collecting duct.

* Increasing the permeability of the medullary portion of the collecting duct to urea.

* Stimulating NaCl reabsorption by the thick ascending limb of Henle’s loop, distal tubule, and collecting duct.

questions.text: 12. The neural center responsible for explicit memory is
questions.solution:
The hippocampus is the neural centre responsible for explicit memory.

Forms of memory are classified into two types, explicit and implicit:

* Explicit/declarative memory is the memory of factual knowledge about people, places, things, and events. It is associated with consciousness/awareness. It is of 2 types:

*

* Semantic memory (facts), e.g., knowing the capital of India, date of birth, names of people, etc. The parts of the brain involved are the lateral and anterior temporal cortex, as well as the prefrontal cortex.

* Episodic memory (events), e.g., recalling the events that occurred on the first day in college. The parts of the brain involved are the hippocampus, medial temporal lobe, and neocortex. 

* Implicit memory/Non-declarative memory does not involve consciousness or awareness. It is of 4 types:

*

* Procedural memory refers to skills and habits, which, once acquired, become unconscious and automatic, such as riding a bicycle or driving a car. It is processed in the striatum.

* Priming refers to the facilitation of the recognition of words or objects by prior exposure to them. It is dependent on the neocortex.

* Non-associative learning includes habituation and sensitisation. It is dependent on various reflex pathways.

* Associative learning includes classical and operant conditioning, in which one learns about the relationship between one stimulus and another. It is dependent on the amygdala for its emotional responses and the cerebellum for its motor responses.

Pearl PM0907: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

questions.text: 13. The murmur of mitral stenosis corresponds to which part of the ECG?
questions.solution:
The murmur of mitral stenosis corresponds to the P wave of the ECG.

Mitral stenosis leads to increased pressure in the left atrium. Left atrial abnormality may cause broad, notched P waves in the limb leads and a biphasic P wave in lead V1 with a prominent negative component representing delayed depolarisation of the left atria.

P wave may become tall and peaked in the lead II and upright in lead V1 due to severe pulmonary hypertension or when tricuspid stenosis complicates mitral stenosis, leading to right atrial enlargement. The QRS complex is usually normal. In severe pulmonary hypertension, right axis deviation and RV hypertrophy can be seen. 

 Auscultatory findings in mitral stenosis are:

* A mid-diastolic murmur

* The first heart sound (S1) is accentuated

* The opening snap (OS) is after the A2 sound. It is best heard during the expiration and at the apex of the heart

* The OS is followed by a low-pitched, rumbling, mid-diastolic murmur, which is heard best at the apex with the patient in the left lateral recumbent position. This murmur correlates with the severity of the stenosis.

questions.text: 14. Which of the following pulses can be best explained by Frank-Starling law?
questions.solution:
Pulsus Alternans can be explained by the Frank-Starling law. 

Frank-Starling law of the heart states relationship between end-diastolic volume and stroke volume is best represented by the length-tension relationship. The volume of blood ejected by the ventricle depends on the volume present in the ventricle at the end of diastole. The length of the myocytes depends on the volume (and hence tension) present at the end of the diastole, which in turn, depends on the volume returned to the heart, or the venous return. It governs normal ventricular function and ensures that cardiac output equals venous return, within physiological limits.

Pulsus Alternans is seen in left ventricular dysfunction in heart failure and is characterised by alternating strong and weak pulses due to reduced left ventricular contraction in every other cardiac cycle. When the left ventricular contractility is reduced, there is a decrease in stroke volume, leading to a weak pulse and increased residual volume within the ventricles. This increase in residual volume leads to increased end-diastolic volume in the next cardiac cycle, leading to stronger ventricular contractility, greater stroke volume and a stronger pulse. Hence, pulsus alternans follows the Frank-Starling law of the heart.



Other options:

Option A: Pulsus Parvus refers to a weak pulse. Aortic stenosis presents with pulsus parvus et tardus, which is seen as a low-amplitude pulse that rises slowly and has a late peak.

Option B: Pulsus Bisferiens is a pulse with double peaks.

Option D: Pulsus Paradoxus refers to a fall in systolic pressure >10 mmHg with inspiration.

questions.text: 15. The hyponatremia in a hypovolemic patient in case of severe diarrhoea is due to

choices.text: Decreased reabsorption of sodium from kidney
Decreased absorption of sodium from the gut

questions.solution:
The hyponatremia in a hypovolemic patient in case of severe diarrhoea is due to increased secretion of Anti-diuretic hormone (ADH). 

Anti-diuretic hormone, also known as Vasopressin, gets activated in severe diarrhoea, leading to dilutional hyponatremia due to increased water reabsorption from the kidneys. In severe diarrhoea, there is hyponatremia due to increased loss of sodium through faeces, leading to decreased absorption of sodium from the gut.

The body also tries to maintain homeostasis by activating the Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone system (RAAS), leading to increased secretion of aldosterone, which further leads to an increase in sodium reabsorption from the kidneys.

Note: Among options B and C, the best answer is Option C, as it is a more primary mechanism for maintaining homeostasis of water and electrolytes.
